style="font-size:0px;line-height:0;"> </td></tr></tbody></table></div></div><div class="post typography" dir="auto" style="padding: 32px 0 0 0;font-size: 16px;line-height: 26px;"><div class="body markup" dir="auto" style="text-align: initial;font-size: 16px;line-height: 26px;width: 100%;word-break: break-word;margin-bottom: 16px;"><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;margin-top: 0;">Some years, it takes me quite a bit of random wandering and many false starts before I figure out the themes I’m unconsciously orbiting. This year has been particularly bad, but nearly halfway through, I think I have my three lighthouse themes for the year. No wonder my wanderings this year have felt like a chaotic three-body problem orbit. Nobody should try to orbit three themes at once if they can help it. Especially not unconsciously. It’s very nauseating.</p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;"><span>The first theme is </span><em>liveness</em><span>.</span><em> </em><span>The second theme is </span><em>bug-fixing, </em><span>which feels in some ways like a natural dual to liveness (since, at a trivial level of connection, fixing bugs restores liveness to complex systems). The third theme is </span><em>haunting, </em><span>which can be understood as a disembodied liveness. I mean haunting not in an occult sense, but in the analytical sense of </span><a href="https://substack.com/redirect/1b2a2346-bc40-43c6-8298-518db1f79079?j=eyJ1IjoiN2Y5dmkifQ.tARrun8Gd6fgxBaHKojc-AN4cyMC97ipzL_8-KhqqoY" rel="" style="color: rgb(54,55,55);text-decoration: underline;">hauntology</a><span>. It seems obvious in hindsight, but to make sense of the hot theme of embodiment, it makes sense to look at </span><em>dis</em><span>embodiment. I have Sam Chua and the participants of the </span><a href="https://substack.com/redirect/fa69bd6a-fbc9-4e31-abe8-d7151ee3550a?j=eyJ1IjoiN2Y5dmkifQ.tARrun8Gd6fgxBaHKojc-AN4cyMC97ipzL_8-KhqqoY" rel="" style="color: rgb(54,55,55);text-decoration: underline;">workshop</a><span> I just helped facilitate in Bangkok to thank for drawing my attention to haunting as a useful lens.</span></p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;"><span>I sense there are deeper links among the three themes, which might involve debugging Heideggerian ideas and exorcising Heideggerian ghosts to get at.</span><span class="footnote-anchor-email" data-component-name="FootnoteAnchorToDOMStatic" style="font-size: 20px;">¹</span><span> I’ll save bugs and haunting for future essays. This essay is about liveness.</span></p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;"><span>The idea of liveness is not just an emergent focal theme of my own current interests. It feels like the focus of </span><em>all</em><span> currently widespread and urgent-seeming concerns shared by many. </span></p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;"><span>Our anxieties around emerging computing technologies revolves around their alien modes of liveness, which can seem to feed on our own modes. Our cultural anxieties and fears revolve around declining liveness in traditions and grand narratives we are attached to. The so-called meaning crisis is a search for individual and intersubjective liveness undertaken between the Scylla of coercive life-scripts and the Charybdis of enervated post-industrial scriptlessness. The unraveling of institutional and state capacities around the world is an ongoing hemmorhaging of ancient pools and lakes of liveness. Anxieties related to the climate revolve around the displacement of familiar and “natural” modes of planetary liveness by unfamiliar, “unnatural,” and possibly unsustainable Mecha-Gaiazilla forms. An overarching concern with liveness — with worlds dying and being born — defines the </span><a href="https://substack.com/redirect/f70914ad-4bec-41f8-9a73-b99557f65581?j=eyJ1IjoiN2Y5dmkifQ.tARrun8Gd6fgxBaHKojc-AN4cyMC97ipzL_8-KhqqoY" rel="" style="color: rgb(54,55,55);text-decoration: underline;">Gramsci Gap</a><span>.</span></p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;"><span>I see the word itself pop up with increasing frequency in other people’s writing, though I’ve been wary of using it myself until now because it is a fraught word. I’ve been particularly leery of using it in the organic, vitalist way it is often used, and have been casting about for a satisfying machinic, non-humanist understanding of liveness, of the sort embodied in an elemental form by a mechanical clock. I now have one, which I’ll share in a bit. We will be exploring liveness in a universalist, contraptiony way. No vibes allowed, especially culture-specific ones (we’ll use a term I made up in 2017, </span><em><a href="https://substack.com/redirect/9da10acd-d565-4a4a-9b1d-22b7249994e5?j=eyJ1IjoiN2Y5dmkifQ.tARrun8Gd6fgxBaHKojc-AN4cyMC97ipzL_8-KhqqoY" rel="" style="color: rgb(54,55,55);text-decoration: underline;">sentiment superstate</a><span>, </span></em><span>if we need to talk about vibes, and go deeper with hauntological tools). In this essay, which kicks off a new series, I’ll be delving into the the </span><s>vibe</s><span> sentiment superstate of the Gramsci Gap.</span></p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;"><span>The concept of liveness helps us articulate </span><em>why </em><span>we seem to want and pursue the things we do these days. Increasingly our angst revolves not around </span><em>what </em><span>or </span><em>how </em><span>questions, but </span><em>why </em><span>questions, concerning primal desires and motivations. And these </span><em>why </em><span>questions always seem to reduce to a search for viable forms of liveness at every scale from chips to civilizations. All angst seems reducible to </span><em>liveness insecurity. </em><span>There is something very foundational about this. The desire to be alive precedes any other kind of desire, even if it must sometimes be bootstrapped somewhat arbitrarily starting with higher-level desires. And this search for liveness really is characteristic of the period that started around 2015. The 1980s, 1990s, 2000s, and early 2010s did not feel like a planet-wide search for liveness at all scales. At least not the parts and scales I was immersed in. It did not feel like everything and everybody was constantly trying to either recover a fading liveness, or conjure up new and fragile kinds of liveness. Liveness before 2015 was like water, something you could take for granted and forget about.</span></p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">What is liveness, how do we know if it is present, and how can we tell when it is emerging, cohering, or draining away? </p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">A machinic perspective on our world at all scales, from literal clock-like simple machines and infrastructures to civilizations and planet-scale liveness, is I think the most illuminating one to adopt.</p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;"><span>Talk centered on machines in 2025 will inevitably be shaped by concerns relating to </span><em>intelligent </em><span>machines, so I want to assert upfront that liveness is not intelligence. At best, there is an dependency relationship between the two qualities, which I’ll try to unpack.</span></p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;"><span>So even though the question of whether a machine of any sort is </span><em>intelligent </em><span>might seem more urgent and pressing, I’m more interested in whether a machine (physical or conceptual) is </span><em>alive</em><span>. In many critical ways, a mechanical clock sheds more light on that matter than an LLM. A bacterium — viewed as a machine rather than as an entity designated by vitalist fiat as </span><em>living</em><span> — sheds more light than a human genius racing an LLM to the death.</span></p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;"><span>In our always-on protocolizing world, it is also tempting to conflate liveness with the “uptime” of particular life-sign signals, ranging from heartbeats and transactional blockchain clocks to trade flows and streaming broadcasts, to narratives small</span><em> </em><span>and grand. Such signals can serve as useful observables, especially for infrastructural forms of liveness that have a tendency to retreat from view, but should not be conflated with liveness itself. They are fingers pointing at moons.</span></p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;"><span>To peek ahead a bit, liveness is a process condition that emerges through, and as, an evolving entanglement of </span><em>memory</em><span> and </span><em>time</em><span>. The bumper-sticker version of my account of liveness is: </span><em>a process condition in which time tells memory how to grow, and memory tells time which way to point.</em><span> </span></p><div style="font-size: 16px;line-height: 26px;"><hr style="margin: 32px 0;padding: 0;height: 1px;background: #dddddd;border: none;"></div><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;"><em><span>The </span><a href="https://substack.com/redirect/63bd43c0-94ed-4bb7-96f7-749e2912a3e8?j=eyJ1IjoiN2Y5dmkifQ.tARrun8Gd6fgxBaHKojc-AN4cyMC97ipzL_8-KhqqoY" rel="" style="color: rgb(54,55,55);text-decoration: underline;">Contraptions Book club</a><span> May pick is </span><strong>The Printing Revolution in Early Modern Europe by Elizabeth S. Eisenstein</strong><span>. Discussion starts May 25.</span></em></p><div style="font-size: 16px;line-height: 26px;"><hr style="margin: 32px 0;padding: 0;height: 1px;background: #dddddd;border: none;"></div><h2 class="header-anchor-post" style="position: relative;--highlight-bg: rgba(var(--color-bg-accent-themed-rgb), 0.2);font-family: 'SF Pro Display',-apple-system-headline,system-ui,-apple-system,BlinkMacSystemFont,'Segoe UI',Roboto,Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif,'Apple Color Emoji','Segoe UI Emoji','Segoe UI Symbol';font-weight: bold;-webkit-font-smoothing: antialiased;-moz-osx-font-smoothing: antialiased;-webkit-appearance: optimizelegibility;-moz-appearance: optimizelegibility;appearance: optimizelegibility;margin: 1em 0 0.625em 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 1.16em;font-size: 1.625em;">Liveness as Process Condition</h2><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;"><span>Liveness, tautologically, is the state of being alive. All life, both natural and artificial (in the sense of Conway’s Game of Life for instance), possesses liveness, but </span><em>contra </em><span>vitalism, not everything that possesses liveness is life. For a while, I was hopeful that Bergson’s idea of </span><em>elan vital</em><span> might shed light on liveness, but now I am inclined to regard it as just naive vitalism with extra steps.</span></p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;"><span>If we are aiming for non-tautological characterization, I suspect it is best to start by thinking of liveness as a possible condition of certain processes, not a property of a particular class of entities or systems we arbitrarily designate as </span><em>living</em><span>. We can then ask what characterizes that condition. </span></p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">Being attached to an entity-centric view of liveness seems to lead to seductive and charismatic but fundamentally flawed notions like Samo Burja’s notion of “live players” — a concept I was briefly seduced by, but am now convinced is dangerously, perhaps fatally misleading.  Live-player theory is just uncritical idolatry with extra steps.</p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;"><span>Understood as a process condition, liveness may jump across material entity and identity boundaries in unsettling ways. When we speak of Moore’s Law jumping from Intel to TSMC circa 2013 for example, that’s a particular uniquely identifiable instance of liveness leaping across continents, cultures, and histories in a way that disrupts associated memories and temporalities on both sides of the leap. Reading the history of TSMC can and should alter your likely US-centric understanding of even the </span><em>early </em><span>history of Moore’s Law. Morris Chang has suddenly been revealed by recent events to have been there all along, right from the beginning, haunting the story. Understanding this results in a historical revisionism operation that rewrites our collective technological memory in powerful and necessary ways, resulting in Morris Chang and Taiwan playing a much more active, early, and central role in the narrative. Our </span><em>memory </em><span>of Moore’s Law has been reoriented.</span></p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;"><span>But even without such obviously radical narrative ruptures and reorientations that raise or lower the status of contending charismatic entities, liveness </span><em>defines</em><span> entities rather than being defined by them. This is why it is a mistake to subordinate the former to the latter. “Players” appear live or not depending on how liveness is flowing or shifting course in their environments.</span></p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;"><span>I just encountered a very clear example of this effect, in the just-concluded TV show </span><em>Andor, </em><span>which serves as a 2-season prequel to the movie </span><em>Rogue One, </em><span>which itself is a prequel to </span><em>A New Hope. </em><span>I think most Star Wars fans would agree that </span><em>Andor </em><span>is probably the best bit of storytelling in the extended universe. It is is the story with the most </span><em>liveness</em><span>. </span></p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;"><span>I rewatched </span><em>Rogue One </em><span>again after finishing </span><em>Andor, </em><span>and was struck by how my response to the movie had been subtly but decisively altered by the show. When I first watched it, the character of Jyn Erso seemed like the protagonist and that of Andor Cassian like a sidekick. This time, the roles seemed reversed. That’s some powerful refactoring of perception, when a prequel genuinely alters how you view the thing it is a prequel to. </span></p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;"><span>But the effect was deeper. In the larger Star Wars cosmology, Jyn is a character of almost-mythic proportions, a sort of minor member of the Skywalker tier of demigods, while Andor (like Din Djarin the Mandalorian) is a character of human proportions. One of the fascinating things about the evolution of the </span><em>Star Wars </em><span>is the gradual shift from mythic-scale to human-scale characters in the storytelling; from </span><a href="https://substack.com/redirect/0ed22d53-c0c4-47bd-b8ab-dce048caf347?j=eyJ1IjoiN2Y5dmkifQ.tARrun8Gd6fgxBaHKojc-AN4cyMC97ipzL_8-KhqqoY" rel="" style="color: rgb(54,55,55);text-decoration: underline;">special people to strange rules</a><span>. This seems to have really pumped up the liveness of the universe. The grander epic-arc movies seem curiously enervated now, once you’ve been immersed in the more intense liveness of the better TV shows. The epic-scale characters now almost seem like sideshow cartoons in the  universe that was created for them. I need to update my old </span><a href="https://substack.com/redirect/5d0ac42e-ebdd-4888-9cc7-398b80363901?j=eyJ1IjoiN2Y5dmkifQ.tARrun8Gd6fgxBaHKojc-AN4cyMC97ipzL_8-KhqqoY" rel="" style="color: rgb(54,55,55);text-decoration: underline;">Epics vs. Lore</a><span> thesis in light of this observation I think.</span></p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">Anyway, the takeaway from that little Star Wars sidebar is that liveness is a property of a process — storytelling in this case — and as it flows and reflows, the apparent being-locked liveness of entities can change radically. Apparent live players can get flattened into cartoons, and vice-versa.</p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;"><span>While in many cases, liveness and entity persistence coincide, constituting the “life” of an entity regarded as “alive,” the two are not the same, and the process condition is the more basic phenomenon. Indeed, the disembodied “phantom heads” of powerful leaders, as a client of mine once put it, can “haunt” organizations long after they are dead or departed, as the ghost of Steve Jobs still haunts Apple. This hauntological understanding of liveness is not vitalist. This sort of liveness can prosaically exist, distributed across many minds and processes, even if it is notionally associated with a single human. The Steve Jobs Process really </span><em>is </em><span>still live and running at Apple, because if never </span><em>was </em><span>co-extensive with the individual being of Steve Jobs. It was a </span><s>vibe</s><span> sentiment superstate covering the mutualist intersubjectivity of a largish sub-Dunbar cabal around Steve Jobs, with Jobs himself constituting only a small, if highly visible, part of it. The myth really was larger than the individual. Similarly, the Bezos process is still running at Amazon, even though he has departed. In both cases, the liveness is not at the level of the individual entities most obviously associated with it.</span></p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;"><span>The classic exchange between Ducard (Liam Neeson) and Bruce Wayne (Christian Bale) in </span><em>Batman Begins </em><span>points to this idea in a rather on-the-nose way:</span></p><blockquote style="border-left: 4px solid #e85c57;margin: 20px 0;padding: 0;"><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);margin-left: 20px;line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">Henri Ducard: …A vigilante is just a man lost in the scramble for his own gratification. He can be destroyed, or locked up. But if you make yourself more than just a man, if you devote yourself to an ideal, and if they can't stop you, then you become something else entirely.</p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);margin-left: 20px;line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">Bruce Wayne: Which is?</p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);margin-left: 20px;line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">Henri Ducard: Legend, Mr. Wayne.</p></blockquote><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;margin-bottom: 0;"><span>In fact, as I’ll argue, one test for liveness is the ability of a process to sustain a certain amount of observable and legible entity-hood within itself, </span><em>but not too much. </em><span>When the entity captures the liveness, the liveness dies. The process must ride the tension between </span><em>being</em><span> and </span><em>becoming</em><span> while resisting reduction to either. When that happens, living legends are born...</span></p></div></div><div class="paywall paywall-white-background" data-testid="paywall" data-component-name="Paywall" role="region" aria-label="Paywall" # [In Search of Liveness](https://substack.com/app-link/post?publication_id=9973&post_id=163729560&utm_source=post-email-title&utm_campaign=email-post-title&isFreemail=true&r=7f9vi&token=eyJ1c2VyX2lkIjoxMjQ2OTk1MCwicG9zdF9pZCI6MTYzNzI5NTYwLCJpYXQiOjE3NDc1MTE1MTgsImV4cCI6MTc1MDEwMzUxOCwiaXNzIjoicHViLTk5NzMiLCJzdWIiOiJwb3N0LXJlYWN0aW9uIn0.cUY11IDxy4GA_eO2O_OZhw_zWi4orFd-QMv3qkv-GEU)

### The common denominator of all our concerns

[Venkatesh Rao](https://substack.com/@contraptions)

May 17

∙

Preview

[![](https://substackcdn.com/image/fetch/w_36,c_scale,f_png,q_auto:good,fl_progressive:steep/https%3A%2F%2Fsubstack.com%2Ficon%2FLucideShare2%3Fv%3D4%26height%3D36%26fill%3Dnone%26stroke%3D%2523808080%26strokeWidth%3D2)](https://substack.com/app-link/post?publication_id=9973&post_id=163729560&utm_source=substack&utm_medium=email&utm_content=share&utm_campaign=email-share&action=share&triggerShare=true&isFreemail=true&r=7f9vi&token=eyJ1c2VyX2lkIjoxMjQ2OTk1MCwicG9zdF9pZCI6MTYzNzI5NTYwLCJpYXQiOjE3NDc1MTE1MTgsImV4cCI6MTc1MDEwMzUxOCwiaXNzIjoicHViLTk5NzMiLCJzdWIiOiJwb3N0LXJlYWN0aW9uIn0.cUY11IDxy4GA_eO2O_OZhw_zWi4orFd-QMv3qkv-GEU)

[

READ IN APP![](https://substackcdn.com/image/fetch/w_36,c_scale,f_png,q_auto:good,fl_progressive:steep/https%3A%2F%2Fsubstack.com%2Ficon%2FLucideArrowUpRight%3Fv%3D4%26height%3D36%26fill%3Dnone%26stroke%3D%2523808080%26strokeWidth%3D2)](https://open.substack.com/pub/contraptions/p/in-search-of-liveness?utm_source=email&redirect=app-store&utm_campaign=email-read-in-app)

 

Some years, it takes me quite a bit of random wandering and many false starts before I figure out the themes I’m unconsciously orbiting. This year has been particularly bad, but nearly halfway through, I think I have my three lighthouse themes for the year. No wonder my wanderings this year have felt like a chaotic three-body problem orbit. Nobody should try to orbit three themes at once if they can help it. Especially not unconsciously. It’s very nauseating.

The first theme is *liveness*. The second theme is *bug-fixing,* which feels in some ways like a natural dual to liveness (since, at a trivial level of connection, fixing bugs restores liveness to complex systems). The third theme is *haunting,* which can be understood as a disembodied liveness. I mean haunting not in an occult sense, but in the analytical sense of [hauntology](https://substack.com/redirect/1b2a2346-bc40-43c6-8298-518db1f79079?j=eyJ1IjoiN2Y5dmkifQ.tARrun8Gd6fgxBaHKojc-AN4cyMC97ipzL_8-KhqqoY). It seems obvious in hindsight, but to make sense of the hot theme of embodiment, it makes sense to look at *dis*embodiment. I have Sam Chua and the participants of the [workshop](https://substack.com/redirect/fa69bd6a-fbc9-4e31-abe8-d7151ee3550a?j=eyJ1IjoiN2Y5dmkifQ.tARrun8Gd6fgxBaHKojc-AN4cyMC97ipzL_8-KhqqoY) I just helped facilitate in Bangkok to thank for drawing my attention to haunting as a useful lens.

I sense there are deeper links among the three themes, which might involve debugging Heideggerian ideas and exorcising Heideggerian ghosts to get at.¹ I’ll save bugs and haunting for future essays. This essay is about liveness.

The idea of liveness is not just an emergent focal theme of my own current interests. It feels like the focus of *all* currently widespread and urgent-seeming concerns shared by many.

Our anxieties around emerging computing technologies revolves around their alien modes of liveness, which can seem to feed on our own modes. Our cultural anxieties and fears revolve around declining liveness in traditions and grand narratives we are attached to. The so-called meaning crisis is a search for individual and intersubjective liveness undertaken between the Scylla of coercive life-scripts and the Charybdis of enervated post-industrial scriptlessness. The unraveling of institutional and state capacities around the world is an ongoing hemmorhaging of ancient pools and lakes of liveness. Anxieties related to the climate revolve around the displacement of familiar and “natural” modes of planetary liveness by unfamiliar, “unnatural,” and possibly unsustainable Mecha-Gaiazilla forms. An overarching concern with liveness — with worlds dying and being born — defines the [Gramsci Gap](https://substack.com/redirect/f70914ad-4bec-41f8-9a73-b99557f65581?j=eyJ1IjoiN2Y5dmkifQ.tARrun8Gd6fgxBaHKojc-AN4cyMC97ipzL_8-KhqqoY).

I see the word itself pop up with increasing frequency in other people’s writing, though I’ve been wary of using it myself until now because it is a fraught word. I’ve been particularly leery of using it in the organic, vitalist way it is often used, and have been casting about for a satisfying machinic, non-humanist understanding of liveness, of the sort embodied in an elemental form by a mechanical clock. I now have one, which I’ll share in a bit. We will be exploring liveness in a universalist, contraptiony way. No vibes allowed, especially culture-specific ones (we’ll use a term I made up in 2017, *[sentiment superstate](https://substack.com/redirect/9da10acd-d565-4a4a-9b1d-22b7249994e5?j=eyJ1IjoiN2Y5dmkifQ.tARrun8Gd6fgxBaHKojc-AN4cyMC97ipzL_8-KhqqoY),* if we need to talk about vibes, and go deeper with hauntological tools). In this essay, which kicks off a new series, I’ll be delving into the the vibe sentiment superstate of the Gramsci Gap.

The concept of liveness helps us articulate *why* we seem to want and pursue the things we do these days. Increasingly our angst revolves not around *what* or *how* questions, but *why* questions, concerning primal desires and motivations. And these *why* questions always seem to reduce to a search for viable forms of liveness at every scale from chips to civilizations. All angst seems reducible to *liveness insecurity.* There is something very foundational about this. The desire to be alive precedes any other kind of desire, even if it must sometimes be bootstrapped somewhat arbitrarily starting with higher-level desires. And this search for liveness really is characteristic of the period that started around 2015. The 1980s, 1990s, 2000s, and early 2010s did not feel like a planet-wide search for liveness at all scales. At least not the parts and scales I was immersed in. It did not feel like everything and everybody was constantly trying to either recover a fading liveness, or conjure up new and fragile kinds of liveness. Liveness before 2015 was like water, something you could take for granted and forget about.

What is liveness, how do we know if it is present, and how can we tell when it is emerging, cohering, or draining away?

A machinic perspective on our world at all scales, from literal clock-like simple machines and infrastructures to civilizations and planet-scale liveness, is I think the most illuminating one to adopt.

Talk centered on machines in 2025 will inevitably be shaped by concerns relating to *intelligent* machines, so I want to assert upfront that liveness is not intelligence. At best, there is an dependency relationship between the two qualities, which I’ll try to unpack.

So even though the question of whether a machine of any sort is *intelligent* might seem more urgent and pressing, I’m more interested in whether a machine (physical or conceptual) is *alive*. In many critical ways, a mechanical clock sheds more light on that matter than an LLM. A bacterium — viewed as a machine rather than as an entity designated by vitalist fiat as *living* — sheds more light than a human genius racing an LLM to the death.

In our always-on protocolizing world, it is also tempting to conflate liveness with the “uptime” of particular life-sign signals, ranging from heartbeats and transactional blockchain clocks to trade flows and streaming broadcasts, to narratives small and grand. Such signals can serve as useful observables, especially for infrastructural forms of liveness that have a tendency to retreat from view, but should not be conflated with liveness itself. They are fingers pointing at moons.

To peek ahead a bit, liveness is a process condition that emerges through, and as, an evolving entanglement of *memory* and *time*. The bumper-sticker version of my account of liveness is: *a process condition in which time tells memory how to grow, and memory tells time which way to point.*

* * *

*The [Contraptions Book club](https://substack.com/redirect/63bd43c0-94ed-4bb7-96f7-749e2912a3e8?j=eyJ1IjoiN2Y5dmkifQ.tARrun8Gd6fgxBaHKojc-AN4cyMC97ipzL_8-KhqqoY) May pick is **The Printing Revolution in Early Modern Europe by Elizabeth S. Eisenstein**. Discussion starts May 25.*

* * *

## Liveness as Process Condition

Liveness, tautologically, is the state of being alive. All life, both natural and artificial (in the sense of Conway’s Game of Life for instance), possesses liveness, but *contra* vitalism, not everything that possesses liveness is life. For a while, I was hopeful that Bergson’s idea of *elan vital* might shed light on liveness, but now I am inclined to regard it as just naive vitalism with extra steps.

If we are aiming for non-tautological characterization, I suspect it is best to start by thinking of liveness as a possible condition of certain processes, not a property of a particular class of entities or systems we arbitrarily designate as *living*. We can then ask what characterizes that condition.

Being attached to an entity-centric view of liveness seems to lead to seductive and charismatic but fundamentally flawed notions like Samo Burja’s notion of “live players” — a concept I was briefly seduced by, but am now convinced is dangerously, perhaps fatally misleading. Live-player theory is just uncritical idolatry with extra steps.

Understood as a process condition, liveness may jump across material entity and identity boundaries in unsettling ways. When we speak of Moore’s Law jumping from Intel to TSMC circa 2013 for example, that’s a particular uniquely identifiable instance of liveness leaping across continents, cultures, and histories in a way that disrupts associated memories and temporalities on both sides of the leap. Reading the history of TSMC can and should alter your likely US-centric understanding of even the *early* history of Moore’s Law. Morris Chang has suddenly been revealed by recent events to have been there all along, right from the beginning, haunting the story. Understanding this results in a historical revisionism operation that rewrites our collective technological memory in powerful and necessary ways, resulting in Morris Chang and Taiwan playing a much more active, early, and central role in the narrative. Our *memory* of Moore’s Law has been reoriented.

But even without such obviously radical narrative ruptures and reorientations that raise or lower the status of contending charismatic entities, liveness *defines* entities rather than being defined by them. This is why it is a mistake to subordinate the former to the latter. “Players” appear live or not depending on how liveness is flowing or shifting course in their environments.

I just encountered a very clear example of this effect, in the just-concluded TV show *Andor,* which serves as a 2-season prequel to the movie *Rogue One,* which itself is a prequel to *A New Hope.* I think most Star Wars fans would agree that *Andor* is probably the best bit of storytelling in the extended universe. It is is the story with the most *liveness*.

I rewatched *Rogue One* again after finishing *Andor,* and was struck by how my response to the movie had been subtly but decisively altered by the show. When I first watched it, the character of Jyn Erso seemed like the protagonist and that of Andor Cassian like a sidekick. This time, the roles seemed reversed. That’s some powerful refactoring of perception, when a prequel genuinely alters how you view the thing it is a prequel to.

But the effect was deeper. In the larger Star Wars cosmology, Jyn is a character of almost-mythic proportions, a sort of minor member of the Skywalker tier of demigods, while Andor (like Din Djarin the Mandalorian) is a character of human proportions. One of the fascinating things about the evolution of the *Star Wars* is the gradual shift from mythic-scale to human-scale characters in the storytelling; from [special people to strange rules](https://substack.com/redirect/0ed22d53-c0c4-47bd-b8ab-dce048caf347?j=eyJ1IjoiN2Y5dmkifQ.tARrun8Gd6fgxBaHKojc-AN4cyMC97ipzL_8-KhqqoY). This seems to have really pumped up the liveness of the universe. The grander epic-arc movies seem curiously enervated now, once you’ve been immersed in the more intense liveness of the better TV shows. The epic-scale characters now almost seem like sideshow cartoons in the universe that was created for them. I need to update my old [Epics vs. Lore](https://substack.com/redirect/5d0ac42e-ebdd-4888-9cc7-398b80363901?j=eyJ1IjoiN2Y5dmkifQ.tARrun8Gd6fgxBaHKojc-AN4cyMC97ipzL_8-KhqqoY) thesis in light of this observation I think.

Anyway, the takeaway from that little Star Wars sidebar is that liveness is a property of a process — storytelling in this case — and as it flows and reflows, the apparent being-locked liveness of entities can change radically. Apparent live players can get flattened into cartoons, and vice-versa.

While in many cases, liveness and entity persistence coincide, constituting the “life” of an entity regarded as “alive,” the two are not the same, and the process condition is the more basic phenomenon. Indeed, the disembodied “phantom heads” of powerful leaders, as a client of mine once put it, can “haunt” organizations long after they are dead or departed, as the ghost of Steve Jobs still haunts Apple. This hauntological understanding of liveness is not vitalist. This sort of liveness can prosaically exist, distributed across many minds and processes, even if it is notionally associated with a single human. The Steve Jobs Process really *is* still live and running at Apple, because if never *was* co-extensive with the individual being of Steve Jobs. It was a vibe sentiment superstate covering the mutualist intersubjectivity of a largish sub-Dunbar cabal around Steve Jobs, with Jobs himself constituting only a small, if highly visible, part of it. The myth really was larger than the individual. Similarly, the Bezos process is still running at Amazon, even though he has departed. In both cases, the liveness is not at the level of the individual entities most obviously associated with it.

The classic exchange between Ducard (Liam Neeson) and Bruce Wayne (Christian Bale) in *Batman Begins* points to this idea in a rather on-the-nose way:

> Henri Ducard: …A vigilante is just a man lost in the scramble for his own gratification. He can be destroyed, or locked up. But if you make yourself more than just a man, if you devote yourself to an ideal, and if they can't stop you, then you become something else entirely.
> 
> Bruce Wayne: Which is?
> 
> Henri Ducard: Legend, Mr. Wayne.

In fact, as I’ll argue, one test for liveness is the ability of a process to sustain a certain amount of observable and legible entity-hood within itself, *but not too much.* When the entity captures the liveness, the liveness dies. The process must ride the tension between *being* and *becoming* while resisting reduction to either. When that happens, living legends are born...

subject: 🐙AI Agents Weekly: AlphaEvolve, codex-1, SWE-1, AI Agents vs. Agentic AI, OpenMemory MCP
plainText:
View this post on the web at https://nlp.elvissaravia.com/p/ai-agents-weekly-alphaevolve-codex

In todayâs issue:
Google announced a new coding agent for science
OpenAI releases new SWE agent, codex-1
Windsurf releases new SWE model
OpenMemory MCP, a private memory for MCP clients
New Agent-User Interaction Protocol
Prime Intellect announces INTELLECT-2
Flowise AI announces Flowise 3.0
RL pipeline for training long-horizon language agents
Top AI devs news, research, and much more.
Top Stories
AlphaEvolve
Google DeepMind introduces AlphaEvolve, a Gemini-powered coding agent designed for general-purpose algorithm discovery and optimization. It combines the creative synthesis of LLMs (Gemini Flash and Pro) with automated evaluation in an evolutionary loop to iteratively improve code solutions for complex problems in computing and mathematics.
AlphaEvolve has been deployed across Googleâs ecosystem, improving data center scheduling (recovering 0.7% of compute), accelerating TPU chip design through optimized Verilog rewrites, and boosting Gemini training speed by 1% through improved matrix multiplication routines. It also achieved a 32.5% speedup in low-level GPU kernel optimization (FlashAttention), significantly reducing engineering time.
Beyond infrastructure, AlphaEvolve has made mathematical advances, including discovering a 4Ã4 complex matrix multiplication algorithm using only 48 scalar multiplications, improving over Strassenâs classical result. It also achieved progress on open problems like the 11D kissing number.
The system flexibly applies to any problem where solutions can be encoded in code and verified. In a test of over 50 open math problems, it matched SOTA in ~75% and surpassed it in 20% of cases.
AlphaEvolve represents a shift from symbolic or neural search-only approaches to a hybrid framework where LLMs not only generate code but also evolve and optimize full algorithmic solutions with quantifiable gains across real-world systems. An early access program for academic users is planned.
Blog [ https://substack.com/redirect/679759a0-d668-488c-be64-89d3bd77dbeb?j=eyJ1IjoiN2Y5dmkifQ.tARrun8Gd6fgxBaHKojc-AN4cyMC97ipzL_8-KhqqoY ] | Paper [ https://substack.com/redirect/f983f47d-71b8-40c8-bc99-72aafc53ab20?j=eyJ1IjoiN2Y5dmkifQ.tARrun8Gd6fgxBaHKojc-AN4cyMC97ipzL_8-KhqqoY ]
Codex
OpenAI has launched Codex, a cloud-based software engineering agent powered by codex-1 (a variant of o4-mini fine-tuned for coding). Available in ChatGPT for Pro, Team, and Enterprise users, Codex is designed to take on parallel software tasks like bug fixes, writing features, refactoring, and PR proposals inside isolated cloud sandboxes loaded with your repo.
codex-1 is strong and instruction-aligned â Built using RL on real-world software tasks, codex-1 outperforms o3 and o4-mini on internal benchmarks and SWE-Bench. It generates human-like patches that adhere to PR conventions, passes more tests, and handles longer contexts (up to 192k tokens). Even without customization (e.g., AGENTS.md), it performs competitively.
Verifiable and secure task execution â Each task runs in a sandbox with no internet access. Codex reads and edits code, runs tests and linters, and logs every action. It cites terminal logs and test results so users can trace changes, ensuring transparency and allowing for manual review before code integration.
AGENTS.md enables custom behavior â Codex supports repo-scoped config files like AGENTS.md to instruct how to run tests, navigate the codebase, and format PRs. This makes Codex behave more like a trained teammate familiar with your project's norms.
CLI and mini model for local use â Codex CLI, launched earlier, now includes a lightweight codex-mini (based on o4-mini) optimized for fast code Q&A and editing. It supports login via ChatGPT and gives Pro users $50 in API credits. This allows devs to use Codex in terminals and IDEs for tighter, real-time workflows.
Used across the industry â Early partners like Cisco, Superhuman, and Temporal use Codex to refactor, debug, write tests, and assist PMs with code changes. It helps developers stay in flow by offloading background tasks, much like an AI teammate.
Blog [ https://substack.com/redirect/bc977f40-afee-4df5-95f7-8feb9bc0992b?j=eyJ1IjoiN2Y5dmkifQ.tARrun8Gd6fgxBaHKojc-AN4cyMC97ipzL_8-KhqqoY ]
AI Agents vs. Agentic AI
This survey clarifies the conceptual and practical distinctions between AI Agents and Agentic AI, offering a structured taxonomy, mapping their applications, and analyzing associated challenges. The authors define AI Agents as modular systems built on large language or image models (LLMs/LIMs), mainly designed for narrow, task-specific automation, like customer support bots, email assistants, and scheduling tools. These agents are characterized by autonomy within bounded domains, reactivity, and task specificity, but generally operate as single-entity systems that leverage external tools and prompt engineering to complete well-defined functions.
Agentic AI, by contrast, is presented as a paradigmatic leap: these are multi-agent systems with persistent memory, dynamic task decomposition, role specialization, and orchestrated autonomy. Agentic AI systems excel in applications requiring collaborative intelligence, such as research automation, robotic swarms, or complex medical decision support, by coordinating multiple specialized agents to achieve broader, adaptive goals. The review highlights several key differences:
Architecture and Mechanisms: AI Agents rely on tool-augmented LLMs and limited planning, while Agentic AI integrates distributed agents, persistent memory, orchestration/meta-agents, and advanced planning methods like ReAct and Chain-of-Thought prompting.
Interaction and Autonomy: AI Agents act independently within a single workflow, whereas Agentic AI features inter-agent communication, contextual adaptation, and higher-level autonomy for complex, multi-step tasks.
Applications: AI Agents are widely deployed for focused automation (e.g., enterprise search, basic reporting), while Agentic AI enables more ambitious automation, multi-agent research assistants, collaborative robotics, and adaptive workflow management.
Challenges: AI Agents are limited by shallow reasoning, prompt brittleness, hallucinations, and a lack of causal understanding. Agentic AI systems face amplified challenges, coordination bottlenecks, error cascades, unpredictability of emergent behaviors, explainability deficits, and governance/ethical risks.
Paper [ https://substack.com/redirect/cc8f56e7-c608-46b3-b696-ef7bd5274fc6?j=eyJ1IjoiN2Y5dmkifQ.tARrun8Gd6fgxBaHKojc-AN4cyMC97ipzL_8-KhqqoY ]
Windsurfâs SWE-1 Model
Windsurf introduces SWE-1, a new family of models built to accelerate the full software engineering lifecycle, not just coding. The lineup includes SWE-1 (frontier-level, Claude 3.5 Sonnet-tier performance), SWE-1-lite (free-for-all Cascade Base replacement), and SWE-1-mini (ultra-fast model powering Windsurf Tab). Rather than optimizing for one-shot code generation, SWE-1 is trained for long-horizon workflows, enabling reasoning over incomplete states, switching between tools (like the terminal or editor), and co-working with users via a âshared timelineâ architecture they call flow awareness.
Key takeaways:
Frontier-class performance, cheaper cost: SWE-1 closely rivals foundation models from top labs in offline evaluations and blind production tests, particularly in agentic coding tasks within Cascade. It beats mid-sized and open-weight models across the board.
Human-in-the-loop excellence: Windsurf designed two SWE benchmarksâone measuring follow-up coding in partial task contexts, and another assessing end-to-end task resolution. SWE-1 excelled at both, with strong daily contribution rates and high retention in real-world usage.
Flow-aware training paradigm: Central to SWE-1âs strength is its grounding in Windsurf's flow system, where both human and AI actions live on a shared timeline. This enables seamless turn-taking, course correction, and persistent context across tools like terminal, browser, clipboard, and IDE.
From tool-calling to predictive action: While SWE-1 focuses on high-quality task reasoning and generation, the mini variant is optimized for predictive passivity (Tab suggestions), showing the extensibility of their training methodology across latency tiers.
Blog [ https://substack.com/redirect/0d0f3006-0239-4353-b61c-d2a4732160ff?j=eyJ1IjoiN2Y5dmkifQ.tARrun8Gd6fgxBaHKojc-AN4cyMC97ipzL_8-KhqqoY ]
AG-UI:  Agent-User Interaction protocol
AG-UI is a lightweight, open protocol designed to unify how frontend applications interact with AI agents. Developed through real-world feedback from CopilotKit and collaborations with frameworks like LangGraph, CrewAI, and AG2, it introduces a standardized event-based system that enables real-time, agentic interactions inside apps.
Key features include support for 16 standard event types, flexible input/output handling, and compatibility with various transports (WebSockets, SSE, etc.). Middleware ensures interoperability even across loosely matched event formats. The protocol supports rich functionality such as streaming chat, frontend tool use, real-time state sync, and generative UI updates. It includes ready-to-use SDKs (TypeScript and Python), a reference HTTP implementation, and React integrations.
AG-UI is already adopted by major agent frameworks and aims to become a universal interface layer between LLM agents and frontend environments. It allows developers to build context-enriched, human-in-the-loop interfaces quickly. The project is open-source and invites community contributions across frameworks, connectors, and demos.
GitHub [ https://substack.com/redirect/9dac6026-cc11-4d25-9973-607d5c1bff3d?j=eyJ1IjoiN2Y5dmkifQ.tARrun8Gd6fgxBaHKojc-AN4cyMC97ipzL_8-KhqqoY ]
Top Picks
AI Dev News
Prime Intellect announces [ https://substack.com/redirect/8a638448-9c7f-429e-9ead-fa3128f7750a?j=eyJ1IjoiN2Y5dmkifQ.tARrun8Gd6fgxBaHKojc-AN4cyMC97ipzL_8-KhqqoY ] INTELLECT-2, an open-source 32B parameter model that was trained via globally distributed RL. 
Contextual AI introduces [ https://substack.com/redirect/ba5c0318-4323-4ea1-95a8-be4bfbbbb2fc?j=eyJ1IjoiN2Y5dmkifQ.tARrun8Gd6fgxBaHKojc-AN4cyMC97ipzL_8-KhqqoY ] a document parser thatâs built specifically for RAG systems. 
muscle-mem [ https://substack.com/redirect/4b644951-4e5a-4efa-a84a-b8ce85cdeb6f?j=eyJ1IjoiN2Y5dmkifQ.tARrun8Gd6fgxBaHKojc-AN4cyMC97ipzL_8-KhqqoY ] is a behavior cache for AI agents.
Qwen releases [ https://substack.com/redirect/273d334b-9af2-4b1e-ad80-a73dab2a6ff6?j=eyJ1IjoiN2Y5dmkifQ.tARrun8Gd6fgxBaHKojc-AN4cyMC97ipzL_8-KhqqoY ] quantized models of Qwen3, including formats like GGUF, AWQ, and GPTQ. 
Supermemory Infinite Chat [ https://substack.com/redirect/fe7996f1-d204-4a3e-8e61-2e0324d3d2de?j=eyJ1IjoiN2Y5dmkifQ.tARrun8Gd6fgxBaHKojc-AN4cyMC97ipzL_8-KhqqoY ] enables unlimited-context chat by acting as a transparent proxy in front of OpenAI-compatible APIs. It intelligently manages long conversations with smart chunking and retrieval, reducing token costs by up to 70% and eliminating token limits, all without impacting latency or requiring code changes.
Artificial Analysis reports [ https://substack.com/redirect/323b369f-8cda-46ca-bf0d-80399c01d595?j=eyJ1IjoiN2Y5dmkifQ.tARrun8Gd6fgxBaHKojc-AN4cyMC97ipzL_8-KhqqoY ] that Kling 2.0 is the leading image-to-video model, surpassing Veo 2 and Runway Gen 4 in their Video Gen Arena. 
Tools & Product Updates
Flowise AI announces [ https://substack.com/redirect/5033895c-af9f-49fc-8ce9-3ed1b3772717?j=eyJ1IjoiN2Y5dmkifQ.tARrun8Gd6fgxBaHKojc-AN4cyMC97ipzL_8-KhqqoY ] Flowise 3.0 to help build complex AI agents from a simple description of the idea. 
mem0 launches [ https://substack.com/redirect/01d5b307-3141-4270-9efa-71c84c54e101?j=eyJ1IjoiN2Y5dmkifQ.tARrun8Gd6fgxBaHKojc-AN4cyMC97ipzL_8-KhqqoY ] OpenMemory MCP, a private memory for MCP clients.
OpenAI has made [ https://substack.com/redirect/43eac271-73e3-465f-b262-4c46a355def9?j=eyJ1IjoiN2Y5dmkifQ.tARrun8Gd6fgxBaHKojc-AN4cyMC97ipzL_8-KhqqoY ] GPT-4.1 directly available in ChatGPT. 
Qwen offers [ https://substack.com/redirect/90263098-aa71-4b7f-9eaa-2dba80dd1240?j=eyJ1IjoiN2Y5dmkifQ.tARrun8Gd6fgxBaHKojc-AN4cyMC97ipzL_8-KhqqoY ] a Deep Research feature on Qwenâs Chat. 
AI SDK now offers [ https://substack.com/redirect/8756c43e-b62f-40f1-a3b3-172266519f0a?j=eyJ1IjoiN2Y5dmkifQ.tARrun8Gd6fgxBaHKojc-AN4cyMC97ipzL_8-KhqqoY ] a diffusion language model through its playground. 
Granola launches [ https://substack.com/redirect/57b65a3d-616e-49f1-b7b1-a111d935506a?j=eyJ1IjoiN2Y5dmkifQ.tARrun8Gd6fgxBaHKojc-AN4cyMC97ipzL_8-KhqqoY ] Granola 2.0, a tool that transforms meeting notes into a searchable, AI-powered team memory system with shared folders, smart chat, and source-linked insights. With new support for top reasoning models and $43M in Series B funding, it aims to become an intelligent workspace for collaborative decision-making.
Notion launches [ https://substack.com/redirect/3f270aba-5cb4-4293-adf3-232d4fb9ea2f?j=eyJ1IjoiN2Y5dmkifQ.tARrun8Gd6fgxBaHKojc-AN4cyMC97ipzL_8-KhqqoY ] new AI features, including AI meeting notes, enterprise search, research mode, and the ability to chat with AI models. 
Research & Education
HealthBench [ https://substack.com/redirect/5b050d73-4843-41e9-b5dc-d6a5a45b3813?j=eyJ1IjoiN2Y5dmkifQ.tARrun8Gd6fgxBaHKojc-AN4cyMC97ipzL_8-KhqqoY ] is OpenAI's new benchmark for evaluating AI model performance in realistic health scenarios, built with input from 262 physicians across 60 countries. It features 5,000 multi-turn, multilingual conversations graded by physician-written rubrics and shows o3 as the current top-performing model, surpassing Claude 3.7 Sonnet and Gemini 2.5 Pro in safety, accuracy, and reasoning.
SkyRL-v0 introduces [ https://substack.com/redirect/81189c06-fe1c-4905-ace1-1456d2684d9a?j=eyJ1IjoiN2Y5dmkifQ.tARrun8Gd6fgxBaHKojc-AN4cyMC97ipzL_8-KhqqoY ] a scalable RL pipeline for training real-world, long-horizon language agents, demonstrating strong gains on SWE-Bench with up to 4â6x rollout efficiency and notable performance boosts across 7B, 8B, and 14B models. It tackles major challenges in environment scaling and async rollout execution by combining VeRL, OpenHands, and novel infrastructure like remote sandboxing and pipelined generation.
Fireworks AI published [ https://substack.com/redirect/8bf3dd1a-5a01-41df-8d6d-931396771bd4?j=eyJ1IjoiN2Y5dmkifQ.tARrun8Gd6fgxBaHKojc-AN4cyMC97ipzL_8-KhqqoY ] a new tutorial on how to run SFT with LoRA on their Fireworks AI platform.
LangChain introduces [ https://substack.com/redirect/2453080e-4095-4db3-9b65-c9289dc1cd42?j=eyJ1IjoiN2Y5dmkifQ.tARrun8Gd6fgxBaHKojc-AN4cyMC97ipzL_8-KhqqoY ] ambient agents, a new agent design pattern that listens to event streams and interacts only when needed, reducing user burden and enabling multitasking. Powered by LangGraph, the system supports human-in-the-loop workflows (notify, question, review), long-term memory, cron jobs, and now includes an email assistant as both a hosted and open-source reference.
OpenAI has launched [ https://substack.com/redirect/11787d11-11b2-4e8e-917d-b5545fd1e324?j=eyJ1IjoiN2Y5dmkifQ.tARrun8Gd6fgxBaHKojc-AN4cyMC97ipzL_8-KhqqoY ] a Safety Evaluations Hub to transparently share ongoing safety and performance metrics for its models across four key areas: harmful content, jailbreak resistance, hallucinations, and instruction hierarchy adherence. The latest results show strong safety in standard refusal and human-sourced jailbreaks (notably GPT-4.5 and o3), but variability remains in hallucination accuracy and robustness against adversarial jailbreaks like StrongReject.
DeepLearning.AI announces [ https://substack.com/redirect/9d01f7dc-7141-4f1e-b7d5-51c73b006dfc?j=eyJ1IjoiN2Y5dmkifQ.tARrun8Gd6fgxBaHKojc-AN4cyMC97ipzL_8-KhqqoY ] a new short course on MCP. 
OpenAI releases [ https://substack.com/redirect/6780f993-6569-435b-94a8-36de0f3edfd5?j=eyJ1IjoiN2Y5dmkifQ.tARrun8Gd6fgxBaHKojc-AN4cyMC97ipzL_8-KhqqoY ] prompting guide for GPT-4.1.

Unsubscribe https://substack..EeweXjYAIjAjPtAmx336cYe6x56vwaLCb6uJ03vai2E?

introduces AlphaEvolve, a Gemini-powered coding agent designed for general-purpose algorithm discovery and optimization. It combines the creative synthesis of LLMs (Gemini Flash and Pro) with automated evaluation in an evolutionary loop to iteratively improve code solutions for complex problems in computing and mathematics.</p><ul style="margin-top: 0;padding: 0;"><li style="margin: 8px 0 0 32px;mso-special-format: bullet;"><p style="color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;margin-bottom: 0;box-sizing: border-box;padding-left: 4px;font-size: 16px;margin: 0;">AlphaEvolve has been deployed across Google’s ecosystem, improving data center scheduling (recovering 0.7% of compute), accelerating TPU chip design through optimized Verilog rewrites, and boosting Gemini training speed by 1% through improved matrix multiplication routines. It also achieved a 32.5% speedup in low-level GPU kernel optimization (FlashAttention), significantly reducing engineering time.</p></li><li style="margin: 8px 0 0 32px;mso-special-format: bullet;"><p style="color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;margin-bottom: 0;box-sizing: border-box;padding-left: 4px;font-size: 16px;margin: 0;">Beyond infrastructure, AlphaEvolve has made mathematical advances, including discovering a 4×4 complex matrix multiplication algorithm using only 48 scalar multiplications, improving over Strassen’s classical result. It also achieved progress on open problems like the 11D kissing number.</p></li><li style="margin: 8px 0 0 32px;mso-special-format: bullet;"><p style="color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;margin-bottom: 0;box-sizing: border-box;padding-left: 4px;font-size: 16px;margin: 0;">The system flexibly applies to any problem where solutions can be encoded in code and verified. In a test of over 50 open math problems, it matched SOTA in ~75% and surpassed it in 20% of cases.</p></li><li style="margin: 8px 0 0 32px;mso-special-format: bullet;"><p style="color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;margin-bottom: 0;box-sizing: border-box;padding-left: 4px;font-size: 16px;margin: 0;">AlphaEvolve represents a shift from symbolic or neural search-only approaches to a hybrid framework where LLMs not only generate code but also evolve and optimize full algorithmic solutions with quantifiable gains across real-world systems. An early access program for academic users is planned.</p></li></ul><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;"><strong><a Codex, a cloud-based software engineering agent powered by codex-1 (a variant of o4-mini fine-tuned for coding). Available in ChatGPT for Pro, Team, and Enterprise users, Codex is designed to take on parallel software tasks like bug fixes, writing features, refactoring, and PR proposals inside isolated cloud sandboxes loaded with your repo.</p><ul style="margin-top: 0;padding: 0;"><li style="margin: 8px 0 0 32px;mso-special-format: bullet;"><p style="color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;margin-bottom: 0;box-sizing: border-box;padding-left: 4px;font-size: 16px;margin: 0;"><strong>codex-1 is strong and instruction-aligned</strong><span> – Built using RL on real-world software tasks, codex-1 outperforms o3 and o4-mini on internal benchmarks and SWE-Bench. It generates human-like patches that adhere to PR conventions, passes more tests, and handles longer contexts (up to 192k tokens). Even without customization (e.g., AGENTS.md), it performs competitively.</span></p></li><li style="margin: 8px 0 0 32px;mso-special-format: bullet;"><p style="color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;margin-bottom: 0;box-sizing: border-box;padding-left: 4px;font-size: 16px;margin: 0;"><strong>Verifiable and secure task execution</strong><span> – Each task runs in a sandbox with no internet access. Codex reads and edits code, runs tests and linters, and logs every action. It cites terminal logs and test results so users can trace changes, ensuring transparency and allowing for manual review before code integration.</span></p></li><li style="margin: 8px 0 0 32px;mso-special-format: bullet;"><p style="color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;margin-bottom: 0;box-sizing: border-box;padding-left: 4px;font-size: 16px;margin: 0;"><strong>AGENTS.md enables custom behavior</strong><span> – Codex supports repo-scoped config files like AGENTS.md to instruct how to run tests, navigate the codebase, and format PRs. This makes Codex behave more like a trained teammate familiar with your project's norms.</span></p></li><li style="margin: 8px 0 0 32px;mso-special-format: bullet;"><p style="color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;margin-bottom: 0;box-sizing: border-box;padding-left: 4px;font-size: 16px;margin: 0;"><strong>CLI and mini model for local use</strong><span> – Codex CLI, launched earlier, now includes a lightweight codex-mini (based on o4-mini) optimized for fast code Q&A and editing. It supports login via ChatGPT and gives Pro users $50 in API credits. This allows devs to use Codex in terminals and IDEs for tighter, real-time workflows.</span></p></li><li style="margin: 8px 0 0 32px;mso-special-format: bullet;"><p style="color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;margin-bottom: 0;box-sizing: border-box;padding-left: 4px;font-size: 16px;margin: 0;"><strong>Used across the industry</strong><span> – Early partners like Cisco, Superhuman, and Temporal use Codex to refactor, debug, write tests, and assist PMs with code changes. It helps developers stay in flow by offloading background tasks, much like an AI teammate.</span></p></li></ul><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 0.625em 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 1.16em;font-size: 1.625em;">AI Agents vs. Agentic AI</h2><div class="captioned-image-container-static" style="font-size: 16px;line-height: 26px;margin: 32px style="border: none !important;vertical-align: middle;display: block;-ms-interpolation-mode: bicubic;height: auto;margin-bottom: 0;width: auto !important;max-width: 100% !important;margin: 0 auto;"></a></td><td style="text-align: center;"></td></tr></tbody></table></figure></div><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">This survey clarifies the conceptual and practical distinctions between AI Agents and Agentic AI, offering a structured taxonomy, mapping their applications, and analyzing associated challenges. The authors define AI Agents as modular systems built on large language or image models (LLMs/LIMs), mainly designed for narrow, task-specific automation, like customer support bots, email assistants, and scheduling tools. These agents are characterized by autonomy within bounded domains, reactivity, and task specificity, but generally operate as single-entity systems that leverage external tools and prompt engineering to complete well-defined functions.</p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">Agentic AI, by contrast, is presented as a paradigmatic leap: these are multi-agent systems with persistent memory, dynamic task decomposition, role specialization, and orchestrated autonomy. Agentic AI systems excel in applications requiring collaborative intelligence, such as research automation, robotic swarms, or complex medical decision support, by coordinating multiple specialized agents to achieve broader, adaptive goals. The review highlights several key differences:</p><ul style="margin-top: 0;padding: 0;"><li style="margin: 8px 0 0 32px;mso-special-format: bullet;"><p style="color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;margin-bottom: 0;box-sizing: border-box;padding-left: 4px;font-size: 16px;margin: 0;"><strong>Architecture and Mechanisms:</strong><span> AI Agents rely on tool-augmented LLMs and limited planning, while Agentic AI integrates distributed agents, persistent memory, orchestration/meta-agents, and advanced planning methods like ReAct and Chain-of-Thought prompting.</span></p></li><li style="margin: 8px 0 0 32px;mso-special-format: bullet;"><p style="color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;margin-bottom: 0;box-sizing: border-box;padding-left: 4px;font-size: 16px;margin: 0;"><strong>Interaction and Autonomy:</strong><span> AI Agents act independently within a single workflow, whereas Agentic AI features inter-agent communication, contextual adaptation, and higher-level autonomy for complex, multi-step tasks.</span></p></li><li style="margin: 8px 0 0 32px;mso-special-format: bullet;"><p style="color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;margin-bottom: 0;box-sizing: border-box;padding-left: 4px;font-size: 16px;margin: 0;"><strong>Applications:</strong><span> AI Agents are widely deployed for focused automation (e.g., enterprise search, basic reporting), while Agentic AI enables more ambitious automation, multi-agent research assistants, collaborative robotics, and adaptive workflow management.</span></p></li><li style="margin: 8px 0 0 32px;mso-special-format: bullet;"><p style="color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;margin-bottom: 0;box-sizing: border-box;padding-left: 4px;font-size: 16px;margin: 0;"><strong>Challenges:</strong><span> AI Agents are limited by shallow reasoning, prompt brittleness, hallucinations, and a lack of causal understanding. Agentic AI systems face amplified challenges, coordination bottlenecks, error cascades, unpredictability of emergent behaviors, explainability deficits, and governance/ethical risks.</span></p></li></ul><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;"><strong><a href="https://substack.com/redirect/cc8f56e7-c608-46b3-b696-ef7bd5274fc6?j=eyJ1IjoiN2Y5dmkifQ.tARrun8Gd6fgxBaHKojc-AN4cyMC97ipzL_8-KhqqoY" rel="" style="color: rgb(54,55,55);text-decoration: underline;">Paper</a></strong></p><div style="font-size: 16px;line-height: 26px;"><hr style="margin: 32px 0;padding: 0;height: 1px;background: #e6e6e6;border: none;"></div><h2 auto;"></a></td><td style="text-align: center;"></td></tr></tbody></table></figure></div><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">Windsurf introduces SWE-1, a new family of models built to accelerate the full software engineering lifecycle, not just coding. The lineup includes SWE-1 (frontier-level, Claude 3.5 Sonnet-tier performance), SWE-1-lite (free-for-all Cascade Base replacement), and SWE-1-mini (ultra-fast model powering Windsurf Tab). Rather than optimizing for one-shot code generation, SWE-1 is trained for long-horizon workflows, enabling reasoning over incomplete states, switching between tools (like the terminal or editor), and co-working with users via a “shared timeline” architecture they call flow awareness.</p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">Key takeaways:</p><ul style="margin-top: 0;padding: 0;"><li style="margin: 8px 0 0 32px;mso-special-format: bullet;"><p style="color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;margin-bottom: 0;box-sizing: border-box;padding-left: 4px;font-size: 16px;margin: 0;"><strong>Frontier-class performance, cheaper cost</strong><span>: SWE-1 closely rivals foundation models from top labs in offline evaluations and blind production tests, particularly in agentic coding tasks within Cascade. It beats mid-sized and open-weight models across the board.</span></p></li><li style="margin: 8px 0 0 32px;mso-special-format: bullet;"><p style="color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;margin-bottom: 0;box-sizing: border-box;padding-left: 4px;font-size: 16px;margin: 0;"><strong>Human-in-the-loop excellence</strong><span>: Windsurf designed two SWE benchmarks—one measuring follow-up coding in partial task contexts, and another assessing end-to-end task resolution. SWE-1 excelled at both, with strong daily contribution rates and high retention in real-world usage.</span></p></li><li style="margin: 8px 0 0 32px;mso-special-format: bullet;"><p style="color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;margin-bottom: 0;box-sizing: border-box;padding-left: 4px;font-size: 16px;margin: 0;"><strong>Flow-aware training paradigm</strong><span>: Central to SWE-1’s strength is its grounding in Windsurf's flow system, where both human and AI actions live on a shared timeline. This enables seamless turn-taking, course correction, and persistent context across tools like terminal, browser, clipboard, and IDE.</span></p></li><li style="margin: 8px 0 0 32px;mso-special-format: bullet;"><p style="color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;margin-bottom: 0;box-sizing: border-box;padding-left: 4px;font-size: 16px;margin: 0;"><strong>From tool-calling to predictive action</strong><span>: While SWE-1 focuses on high-quality task reasoning and generation, the mini variant is optimized for predictive passivity (Tab suggestions), showing the extensibility of their training methodology across latency tiers.</span></p></li></ul><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;"><strong><a href="https://substack.com/redirect/0d0f3006-0239-4353-b61c-d2a4732160ff?j=eyJ1IjoiN2Y5dmkifQ.tARrun8Gd6fgxBaHKojc-AN4cyMC97ipzL_8-KhqqoY" rel="" style="color: rgb(54,55,55);text-decoration: open protocol designed to unify how frontend applications interact with AI agents. Developed through real-world feedback from CopilotKit and collaborations with frameworks like LangGraph, CrewAI, and AG2, it introduces a standardized event-based system that enables real-time, agentic interactions inside apps.</p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">Key features include support for 16 standard event types, flexible input/output handling, and compatibility with various transports (WebSockets, SSE, etc.). Middleware ensures interoperability even across loosely matched event formats. The protocol supports rich functionality such as streaming chat, frontend tool use, real-time state sync, and generative UI updates. It includes ready-to-use SDKs (TypeScript and Python), a reference HTTP implementation, and React integrations.</p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">AG-UI is already adopted by major agent frameworks and aims to become a universal interface layer between LLM agents and frontend environments. It allows developers to build context-enriched, human-in-the-loop interfaces quickly. The project is open-source and invites community contributions across frameworks, connectors, and demos.</p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;"><strong><a href="https://substack.com/redirect/9dac6026-cc11-4d25-9973-607d5c1bff3d?j=eyJ1IjoiN2Y5dmkifQ.tARrun8Gd6fgxBaHKojc-AN4cyMC97ipzL_8-KhqqoY" rel="" style="color: underline;">HealthBench</a></strong><span> is OpenAI's new benchmark for evaluating AI model performance in realistic health scenarios, built with input from 262 physicians across 60 countries. It features 5,000 multi-turn, multilingual conversations graded by physician-written rubrics and shows o3 as the current top-performing model, surpassing Claude 3.7 Sonnet and Gemini 2.5 Pro in safety, accuracy, and reasoning.</span></p></li><li style="margin: 8px 0 0 32px;mso-special-format: bullet;"><p style="color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;margin-bottom: 0;box-sizing: border-box;padding-left: 4px;font-size: 16px;margin: 0;"><span>SkyRL-v0 </span><strong><a href="https://substack.com/redirect/81189c06-fe1c-4905-ace1-1456d2684d9a?j=eyJ1IjoiN2Y5dmkifQ.tARrun8Gd6fgxBaHKojc-AN4cyMC97ipzL_8-KhqqoY" rel="" style="color: rgb(54,55,55);text-decoration: underline;">introduces</a></strong><span> a scalable RL pipeline for training real-world, long-horizon language agents, demonstrating strong gains on SWE-Bench with up to 4–6x rollout efficiency and notable performance boosts across 7B, 8B, and 14B models. It tackles major challenges in environment scaling and async rollout execution by combining VeRL, OpenHands, and novel infrastructure like remote sandboxing and pipelined generation.</span></p></li><li style="margin: 8px 0 0 32px;mso-special-format: bullet;"><p style="color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;margin-bottom: 0;box-sizing: border-box;padding-left: 4px;font-size: 16px;margin: 0;"><span>Fireworks AI </span><strong><a href="https://substack.com/redirect/8bf3dd1a-5a01-41df-8d6d-931396771bd4?j=eyJ1IjoiN2Y5dmkifQ.tARrun8Gd6fgxBaHKojc-AN4cyMC97ipzL_8-KhqqoY" rel="" style="color: rgb(54,55,55);text-decoration: underline;">published</a></strong><span> a new tutorial on how to run SFT with LoRA on their Fireworks AI platform.</span></p></li><li style="margin: 8px 0 0 32px;mso-special-format: bullet;"><p style="color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;margin-bottom: 0;box-sizing: border-box;padding-left: 4px;font-size: 16px;margin: 0;"><span>LangChain </span><strong><a href="https://substack.com/redirect/2453080e-4095-4db3-9b65-c9289dc1cd42?j=eyJ1IjoiN2Y5dmkifQ.tARrun8Gd6fgxBaHKojc-AN4cyMC97ipzL_8-KhqqoY" rel="" style="color: rgb(54,55,55);text-decoration: underline;">introduces</a></strong><span> ambient agents, a new agent design pattern that listens to event streams and interacts only when needed, reducing user burden and enabling multitasking. Powered by LangGraph, the system supports human-in-the-loop workflows (notify, question, review), long-term memory, cron jobs, and now includes an email assistant as both a hosted and open-source reference.</span></p></li><li style="margin: 8px 0 0 32px;mso-special-format: bullet;"><p style="color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;margin-bottom: 0;box-sizing: border-box;padding-left: 4px;font-size: 16px;margin: 0;"><span>OpenAI has </span><strong><a href="https://substack.com/redirect/11787d11-11b2-4e8e-917d-b5545fd1e324?j=eyJ1IjoiN2Y5dmkifQ.tARrun8Gd6fgxBaHKojc-AN4cyMC97ipzL_8-KhqqoY" rel="" style="color: rgb(54,55,55);text-decoration: underline;">launched</a></strong><span> a Safety Evaluations Hub to transparently share ongoing safety and performance metrics for its models across four key areas: harmful content, jailbreak resistance, hallucinations, and instruction hierarchy adherence. The latest results show strong safety in standard refusal and human-sourced jailbreaks (notably GPT-4.5 and o3), but variability remains in hallucination accuracy and robustness against adversarial jailbreaks like StrongReject.</span></p></li><li style="margin: 8px 0 0 32px;mso-special-format: bullet;"><p style="color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;margin-bottom: 0;box-sizing: border-box;padding-left: 4px;font-size: 16px;margin: 0;"><span>DeepLearning.AI </span><strong><a # Top Stories

## AlphaEvolve

[![](https://substackcdn.com/image/fetch/w_1100,c_limit,f_auto,q_auto:good,fl_progressive:steep/https%3A%2F%2Fsubstack-post-media.s3.amazonaws.com%2Fpublic%2Fimages%2F8b468d97-e9ac-406d-ba95-bce9e82922bf_616x385.png)](https://substack.com/redirect/9db1884a-59ed-4b5b-be50-64813b1abe33?j=eyJ1IjoiN2Y5dmkifQ.tARrun8Gd6fgxBaHKojc-AN4cyMC97ipzL_8-KhqqoY)

Google DeepMind introduces AlphaEvolve, a Gemini-powered coding agent designed for general-purpose algorithm discovery and optimization. It combines the creative synthesis of LLMs (Gemini Flash and Pro) with automated evaluation in an evolutionary loop to iteratively improve code solutions for complex problems in computing and mathematics.

*   AlphaEvolve has been deployed across Google’s ecosystem, improving data center scheduling (recovering 0.7% of compute), accelerating TPU chip design through optimized Verilog rewrites, and boosting Gemini training speed by 1% through improved matrix multiplication routines. It also achieved a 32.5% speedup in low-level GPU kernel optimization (FlashAttention), significantly reducing engineering time.
    
*   Beyond infrastructure, AlphaEvolve has made mathematical advances, including discovering a 4×4 complex matrix multiplication algorithm using only 48 scalar multiplications, improving over Strassen’s classical result. It also achieved progress on open problems like the 11D kissing number.
    
*   The system flexibly applies to any problem where solutions can be encoded in code and verified. In a test of over 50 open math problems, it matched SOTA in ~75% and surpassed it in 20% of cases.
    
*   AlphaEvolve represents a shift from symbolic or neural search-only approaches to a hybrid framework where LLMs not only generate code but also evolve and optimize full algorithmic solutions with quantifiable gains across real-world systems. An early access program for academic users is planned.

## Codex

[![Dashboard asking ‘What should we code next?’ with a prompt box, repo/branch selectors, and a task list on a pastel code-themed backdrop.](https://substackcdn.com/image/fetch/w_1100,c_limit,f_auto,q_auto:good,fl_progressive:steep/https%3A%2F%2Fsubstack-post-media.s3.amazonaws.com%2Fpublic%2Fimages%2F7053d014-a833-4bf5-bb02-51604b3bb498_3840x2160.webp "Dashboard asking ‘What should we code next?’ with a prompt box, repo/branch selectors, and a task list on a pastel code-themed backdrop.")](https://substack.com/redirect/2b7b0663-bf6b-4ee4-9b7d-0cd8134f1d80?j=eyJ1IjoiN2Y5dmkifQ.tARrun8Gd6fgxBaHKojc-AN4cyMC97ipzL_8-KhqqoY)

OpenAI has launched Codex, a cloud-based software engineering agent powered by codex-1 (a variant of o4-mini fine-tuned for coding). Available in ChatGPT for Pro, Team, and Enterprise users, Codex is designed to take on parallel software tasks like bug fixes, writing features, refactoring, and PR proposals inside isolated cloud sandboxes loaded with your repo.

*   **codex-1 is strong and instruction-aligned** – Built using RL on real-world software tasks, codex-1 outperforms o3 and o4-mini on internal benchmarks and SWE-Bench. It generates human-like patches that adhere to PR conventions, passes more tests, and handles longer contexts (up to 192k tokens). Even without customization (e.g., AGENTS.md), it performs competitively.
    
*   **Verifiable and secure task execution** – Each task runs in a sandbox with no internet access. Codex reads and edits code, runs tests and linters, and logs every action. It cites terminal logs and test results so users can trace changes, ensuring transparency and allowing for manual review before code integration.
    
*   **AGENTS.md enables custom behavior** – Codex supports repo-scoped config files like AGENTS.md to instruct how to run tests, navigate the codebase, and format PRs. This makes Codex behave more like a trained teammate familiar with your project's norms.
    
*   **CLI and mini model for local use** – Codex CLI, launched earlier, now includes a lightweight codex-mini (based on o4-mini) optimized for fast code Q&A and editing. It supports login via ChatGPT and gives Pro users $50 in API credits. This allows devs to use Codex in terminals and IDEs for tighter, real-time workflows.
    
*   **Used across the industry** – Early partners like Cisco, Superhuman, and Temporal use Codex to refactor, debug, write tests, and assist PMs with code changes. It helps developers stay in flow by offloading background tasks, much like an AI teammate.

## AI Agents vs. Agentic AI

[![](https://substackcdn.com/image/fetch/w_1100,c_limit,f_auto,q_auto:good,fl_progressive:steep/https%3A%2F%2Fsubstack-post-media.s3.amazonaws.com%2Fpublic%2Fimages%2F7f59ea83-6d46-4937-9e7a-4abe68d4db52_959x613.png)](https://substack.com/redirect/b29ea514-d671-47f1-b729-741556a11377?j=eyJ1IjoiN2Y5dmkifQ.tARrun8Gd6fgxBaHKojc-AN4cyMC97ipzL_8-KhqqoY)

This survey clarifies the conceptual and practical distinctions between AI Agents and Agentic AI, offering a structured taxonomy, mapping their applications, and analyzing associated challenges. The authors define AI Agents as modular systems built on large language or image models (LLMs/LIMs), mainly designed for narrow, task-specific automation, like customer support bots, email assistants, and scheduling tools. These agents are characterized by autonomy within bounded domains, reactivity, and task specificity, but generally operate as single-entity systems that leverage external tools and prompt engineering to complete well-defined functions.

Agentic AI, by contrast, is presented as a paradigmatic leap: these are multi-agent systems with persistent memory, dynamic task decomposition, role specialization, and orchestrated autonomy. Agentic AI systems excel in applications requiring collaborative intelligence, such as research automation, robotic swarms, or complex medical decision support, by coordinating multiple specialized agents to achieve broader, adaptive goals. The review highlights several key differences:

*   **Architecture and Mechanisms:** AI Agents rely on tool-augmented LLMs and limited planning, while Agentic AI integrates distributed agents, persistent memory, orchestration/meta-agents, and advanced planning methods like ReAct and Chain-of-Thought prompting.
    
*   **Interaction and Autonomy:** AI Agents act independently within a single workflow, whereas Agentic AI features inter-agent communication, contextual adaptation, and higher-level autonomy for complex, multi-step tasks.
    
*   **Applications:** AI Agents are widely deployed for focused automation (e.g., enterprise search, basic reporting), while Agentic AI enables more ambitious automation, multi-agent research assistants, collaborative robotics, and adaptive workflow management.
    
*   **Challenges:** AI Agents are limited by shallow reasoning, prompt brittleness, hallucinations, and a lack of causal understanding. Agentic AI systems face amplified challenges, coordination bottlenecks, error cascades, unpredictability of emergent behaviors, explainability deficits, and governance/ethical risks.
    

**[Paper](https://substack.com/redirect/cc8f56e7-c608-46b3-b696-ef7bd5274fc6?j=eyJ1IjoiN2Y5dmkifQ.tARrun8Gd6fgxBaHKojc-AN4cyMC97ipzL_8-KhqqoY)**

## Windsurf’s SWE-1 Model

[![](https://substackcdn.com/image/fetch/w_1100,c_limit,f_auto,q_auto:good,fl_progressive:steep/https%3A%2F%2Fsubstack-post-media.s3.amazonaws.com%2Fpublic%2Fimages%2Fde277219-15af-4594-bc18-dc25814bda44_969x539.png)](https://substack.com/redirect/cb91a8f4-9803-41de-b14a-44459ad41861?j=eyJ1IjoiN2Y5dmkifQ.tARrun8Gd6fgxBaHKojc-AN4cyMC97ipzL_8-KhqqoY)

Windsurf introduces SWE-1, a new family of models built to accelerate the full software engineering lifecycle, not just coding. The lineup includes SWE-1 (frontier-level, Claude 3.5 Sonnet-tier performance), SWE-1-lite (free-for-all Cascade Base replacement), and SWE-1-mini (ultra-fast model powering Windsurf Tab). Rather than optimizing for one-shot code generation, SWE-1 is trained for long-horizon workflows, enabling reasoning over incomplete states, switching between tools (like the terminal or editor), and co-working with users via a “shared timeline” architecture they call flow awareness.

Key takeaways:

*   **Frontier-class performance, cheaper cost**: SWE-1 closely rivals foundation models from top labs in offline evaluations and blind production tests, particularly in agentic coding tasks within Cascade. It beats mid-sized and open-weight models across the board.
    
*   **Human-in-the-loop excellence**: Windsurf designed two SWE benchmarks—one measuring follow-up coding in partial task contexts, and another assessing end-to-end task resolution. SWE-1 excelled at both, with strong daily contribution rates and high retention in real-world usage.
    
*   **Flow-aware training paradigm**: Central to SWE-1’s strength is its grounding in Windsurf's flow system, where both human and AI actions live on a shared timeline. This enables seamless turn-taking, course correction, and persistent context across tools like terminal, browser, clipboard, and IDE.
    
*   **From tool-calling to predictive action**: While SWE-1 focuses on high-quality task reasoning and generation, the mini variant is optimized for predictive passivity (Tab suggestions), showing the extensibility of their training methodology across latency tiers.
