## AG-UI: Agent-User Interaction protocol

[![ag-ui Logo](https://substackcdn.com/image/fetch/w_1100,c_limit,f_auto,q_auto:good,fl_progressive:steep/https%3A%2F%2Fsubstack-post-media.s3.amazonaws.com%2Fpublic%2Fimages%2F51b825ae-8e86-4d66-b848-016fafda7a21_1551x644.png "ag-ui Logo")](https://substack.com/redirect/d18676ab-7dca-43de-b38d-17257f8514c3?j=eyJ1IjoiN2Y5dmkifQ.tARrun8Gd6fgxBaHKojc-AN4cyMC97ipzL_8-KhqqoY)

AG-UI is a lightweight, open protocol designed to unify how frontend applications interact with AI agents. Developed through real-world feedback from CopilotKit and collaborations with frameworks like LangGraph, CrewAI, and AG2, it introduces a standardized event-based system that enables real-time, agentic interactions inside apps.

Key features include support for 16 standard event types, flexible input/output handling, and compatibility with various transports (WebSockets, SSE, etc.). Middleware ensures interoperability even across loosely matched event formats. The protocol supports rich functionality such as streaming chat, frontend tool use, real-time state sync, and generative UI updates. It includes ready-to-use SDKs (TypeScript and Python), a reference HTTP implementation, and React integrations.

AG-UI is already adopted by major agent frameworks and aims to become a universal interface layer between LLM agents and frontend environments. It allows developers to build context-enriched, human-in-the-loop interfaces quickly. The project is open-source and invites community contributions across frameworks, connectors, and demos.

*   Flowise AI **[announces](https://substack.com/redirect/5033895c-af9f-49fc-8ce9-3ed1b3772717?j=eyJ1IjoiN2Y5dmkifQ.tARrun8Gd6fgxBaHKojc-AN4cyMC97ipzL_8-KhqqoY)** Flowise 3.0 to help build complex AI agents from a simple description of the idea.
    
*   mem0 **[launches](https://substack.com/redirect/01d5b307-3141-4270-9efa-71c84c54e101?j=eyJ1IjoiN2Y5dmkifQ.tARrun8Gd6fgxBaHKojc-AN4cyMC97ipzL_8-KhqqoY)** OpenMemory MCP, a private memory for MCP clients.
    
*   **[OpenAI has made](https://substack.com/redirect/43eac271-73e3-465f-b262-4c46a355def9?j=eyJ1IjoiN2Y5dmkifQ.tARrun8Gd6fgxBaHKojc-AN4cyMC97ipzL_8-KhqqoY)** GPT-4.1 directly available in ChatGPT.
    
*   Qwen **[offers](https://substack.com/redirect/90263098-aa71-4b7f-9eaa-2dba80dd1240?j=eyJ1IjoiN2Y5dmkifQ.tARrun8Gd6fgxBaHKojc-AN4cyMC97ipzL_8-KhqqoY)** a Deep Research feature on Qwen’s Chat.
    
*   AI SDK now **[offers](https://substack.com/redirect/8756c43e-b62f-40f1-a3b3-172266519f0a?j=eyJ1IjoiN2Y5dmkifQ.tARrun8Gd6fgxBaHKojc-AN4cyMC97ipzL_8-KhqqoY)** a diffusion language model through its playground.
    
*   Granola **[launches](https://substack.com/redirect/57b65a3d-616e-49f1-b7b1-a111d935506a?j=eyJ1IjoiN2Y5dmkifQ.tARrun8Gd6fgxBaHKojc-AN4cyMC97ipzL_8-KhqqoY)** Granola 2.0, a tool that transforms meeting notes into a searchable, AI-powered team memory system with shared folders, smart chat, and source-linked insights. With new support for top reasoning models and $43M in Series B funding, it aims to become an intelligent workspace for collaborative decision-making.
    
*   Notion **[launches](https://substack.com/redirect/3f270aba-5cb4-4293-adf3-232d4fb9ea2f?j=eyJ1IjoiN2Y5dmkifQ.tARrun8Gd6fgxBaHKojc-AN4cyMC97ipzL_8-KhqqoY)** new AI features, including AI meeting notes, enterprise search, research mode, and the ability to chat with AI models.
    

* * *

## Research & Education

[![](https://substackcdn.com/image/fetch/w_1100,c_limit,f_auto,q_auto:good,fl_progressive:steep/https%3A%2F%2Fsubstack-post-media.s3.amazonaws.com%2Fpublic%2Fimages%2F085d171a-7557-4e08-a64d-827c7990b937_1219x587.png)](https://substack.com/redirect/b622d2ee-32fa-42c2-98fd-b6b64a93f399?j=eyJ1IjoiN2Y5dmkifQ.tARrun8Gd6fgxBaHKojc-AN4cyMC97ipzL_8-KhqqoY)

*   **[HealthBench](https://substack.com/redirect/5b050d73-4843-41e9-b5dc-d6a5a45b3813?j=eyJ1IjoiN2Y5dmkifQ.tARrun8Gd6fgxBaHKojc-AN4cyMC97ipzL_8-KhqqoY)** is OpenAI's new benchmark for evaluating AI model performance in realistic health scenarios, built with input from 262 physicians across 60 countries. It features 5,000 multi-turn, multilingual conversations graded by physician-written rubrics and shows o3 as the current top-performing model, surpassing Claude 3.7 Sonnet and Gemini 2.5 Pro in safety, accuracy, and reasoning.
    
*   SkyRL-v0 **[introduces](https://substack.com/redirect/81189c06-fe1c-4905-ace1-1456d2684d9a?j=eyJ1IjoiN2Y5dmkifQ.tARrun8Gd6fgxBaHKojc-AN4cyMC97ipzL_8-KhqqoY)** a scalable RL pipeline for training real-world, long-horizon language agents, demonstrating strong gains on SWE-Bench with up to 4–6x rollout efficiency and notable performance boosts across 7B, 8B, and 14B models. It tackles major challenges in environment scaling and async rollout execution by combining VeRL, OpenHands, and novel infrastructure like remote sandboxing and pipelined generation.
    
*   Fireworks AI **[published](https://substack.com/redirect/8bf3dd1a-5a01-41df-8d6d-931396771bd4?j=eyJ1IjoiN2Y5dmkifQ.tARrun8Gd6fgxBaHKojc-AN4cyMC97ipzL_8-KhqqoY)** a new tutorial on how to run SFT with LoRA on their Fireworks AI platform.
    
*   LangChain **[introduces](https://substack.com/redirect/2453080e-4095-4db3-9b65-c9289dc1cd42?j=eyJ1IjoiN2Y5dmkifQ.tARrun8Gd6fgxBaHKojc-AN4cyMC97ipzL_8-KhqqoY)** ambient agents, a new agent design pattern that listens to event streams and interacts only when needed, reducing user burden and enabling multitasking. Powered by LangGraph, the system supports human-in-the-loop workflows (notify, question, review), long-term memory, cron jobs, and now includes an email assistant as both a hosted and open-source reference.
    
*   OpenAI has **[launched](https://substack.com/redirect/11787d11-11b2-4e8e-917d-b5545fd1e324?j=eyJ1IjoiN2Y5dmkifQ.tARrun8Gd6fgxBaHKojc-AN4cyMC97ipzL_8-KhqqoY)** a Safety Evaluations Hub to transparently share ongoing safety and performance metrics for its models across four key areas: harmful content, jailbreak resistance, hallucinations, and instruction hierarchy adherence. The latest results show strong safety in standard refusal and human-sourced jailbreaks (notably GPT-4.5 and o3), but variability remains in hallucination accuracy and robustness against adversarial jailbreaks like StrongReject.
    
*   DeepLearning.AI **[announces](https://substack.com/redirect/9d01f7dc-7141-4f1e-b7d5-51c73b006dfc?j=eyJ1IjoiN2Y5dmkifQ.tARrun8Gd6fgxBaHKojc-AN4cyMC97ipzL_8-KhqqoY)** a new short course on MCP.
    
*   OpenAI **[releases](https://substack.com/redirect/6780f993-6569-435b-94a8-36de0f3edfd5?j=eyJ1IjoiN2Y5dmkifQ.tARrun8Gd6fgxBaHKojc-AN4cyMC97ipzL_8-KhqqoY)** prompting guide for GPT-4.1.
    

 

[![](https://substackcdn.com/image/fetch/w_36,c_scale,f_png,q_auto:good,fl_progressive:steep/https%3A%2F%2Fsubstack.com%2Ficon%2FLucideHeart%3Fv%3D4%26height%3D36%26fill%3Dnone%26stroke%3D%2523808080%26strokeWidth%3D2)Like](https://substack.com/app-link/post?publication_id=103238&post_id=163724810&utm_source=substack&isFreemail=false&submitLike=true&token=eyJ1c2VyX2lkIjoxMjQ2OTk1MCwicG9zdF9pZCI6MTYzNzI0ODEwLCJyZWFjdGlvbiI6IuKdpCIsImlhdCI6MTc0NzUwMjc0NSwiZXhwIjoxNzUwMDk0NzQ1LCJpc3MiOiJwdWItMTAzMjM4Iiwic3ViIjoicmVhY3Rpb24ifQ.4CuWM8p2Wa4laCri01JnnjcFpcbhgsZPO8im3YTx_ac&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=email-reaction&r=7f9vi)

subject: Re: [openai/codex-universal] Deno included in package please ? (Issue #6)
plainText:
terkelg left a comment (openai/codex-universal#6)

I'd also be interested in support for Deno as well. My current setup script looks like this, but it's not ideal and not the[ recommended way to install Deno](https://docs.deno.com/runtime/getting_started/installation/#download-and-install):

```bash
npm install -g deno
deno install --allow-scripts --unsafely-ignore-certificate-errors
```

--

subject: 🟡 Your audience wants answers
plainText:
This email contains a critical lesson every content creator needs
to know.

Now, I'm not explaining what that lesson is up front on purpose.

Science backs me up on this.

Quick storyâ¦

The discovery goes back almost a hundred years, but it's more
relevant today than it was back then.
-----------------------------------------------------------------

Meet Bluma, a psychology student in Berlin.

Bluma becomes obsessed with how waiters and waitresses have
exceptional memory for people's orders during service, but forget
the orders just as quickly afterward.

That's odd, right?

You'd think that once you memorized someone's order that you'd
memorized it?

Bluma has a theory why that's not true. This isn't just
short-term memory. She recruits a bunch of volunteers to a test
whose results will become her doctorate thesis.

Here's how the experiment goes:
-------------------------------

She gives each volunteer some simple puzzles and tasks. Half get
to finish their tasks. Half are interrupted before they can
finish their work.

Afterward, she asks each volunteer what tasks they remember most
clearly.

Guess which tasks and puzzles they can't get out of their minds?

It's the stuff they didn't finish.

Makes sense right?

It's like incompleteness lingersâ¦ seeking closure.

Once we have closure, the mind stops working so hard on the idea,
allowing it to slip from memory unless it's important for other
reasons.

This lingering of unresolved thoughts becomes known as the
Zeigarnik Effect after its discoverer, Bluma Zeigarnik.

This effect is the same reason a song gets stuck in your head.
It's unresolved tension. The brain needs to complete it. Wants to
resolve it. The song is trying to finish itself.

(Btw, the trick to getting the song out is to sing it all the way
to the end. Give yourself that closure.)

So, why does this matter in business?
-------------------------------------

Bluma's experiment uncovers some fundamentals about how human
brains work:

* Our minds crave completion
* We naturally obsess over unresolved stories
* When something is unfinished, we pay closer attention

In writing, we usually refer to using the Zeigarnik Effect as
creating an open loop or a curiosity gap.

It's why Netflix episodes end on a cliffhanger to drive
binge-watching.

It's why email marketers write mysterious subject lines to boost
open rates.

It's why, even though your audience wants answers, you shouldn't
give them to them. At least, not right away.

Because if you have something valuable to share, if you want your
stuff read and consumed, you've got to hold back too.

Or risk losing attention and getting skipped.

Cheers,

â

Rob Lennon
âFounder and CEO, Reactor.is (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/27url3955kfoh8e0w38i3hg63w344hg/owhkhqhwngnq6xhq/aHR0cHM6Ly9yZWFjdG9yLmlz
)â
Founder, Lennon Labs (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/27url3955kfoh8e0w38i3hg63w344hg/z2hghnhe7p7lknfz/aHR0cHM6Ly9sZW5ub25sYWJzLmNvbQ==
)â

â

â
â

PS - This email was inspired by work I'm up to with
writing/solopreneurship legend Erica Schneider this week.

â

We're transforming Hooks, our original course and AI toolkit,
into a new edition, which includes some ridiculously-powerful new
hook-writing bots and prompts. Stuff that makes wielding the
Zeigarnik Effect easy.

â

More on that soon.

113 Cherry St #92768, Seattle, WA 98104-2205
âUnsubscribe (
https://unsubscribe.convertkit-mail2.com/27url3955kfoh8e0w38i3hg63w344hg
) Â· Preferences (
https://preferences.convertkit-mail2.com/27url3955kfoh8e0w38i3hg63w344hg
)â

This email contains a critical lesson every content creator needs to know.

Now, I'm not explaining what that lesson is up front on purpose.

Science backs me up on this.

Quick storyâ¦

The discovery goes back almost a hundred years, but it's more relevant today than it was back then.

Meet Bluma, a psychology student in Berlin.

Bluma becomes obsessed with how waiters and waitresses have exceptional memory for people's orders during service, but forget the orders just as quickly afterward.

That's odd, right?

You'd think that once you memorized someone's order that you'd memorized it?

Bluma has a theory why that's not true. This isn't just short-term memory. She recruits a bunch of volunteers to a test whose results will become her doctorate thesis.

Here's how the experiment goes:

She gives each volunteer some simple puzzles and tasks. Half get to finish their tasks. Half are interrupted before they can finish their work.

Afterward, she asks each volunteer what tasks they remember most clearly.

Guess which tasks and puzzles they can't get out of their minds?

It's the stuff they didn't finish.

Makes sense right?

It's like incompleteness lingersâ¦ seeking closure.

Once we have closure, the mind stops working so hard on the idea, allowing it to slip from memory unless it's important for other reasons.

This lingering of unresolved thoughts becomes known as the Zeigarnik Effect after its discoverer, Bluma Zeigarnik.

This effect is the same reason a song gets stuck in your head. It's unresolved tension. The brain needs to complete it. Wants to resolve it. The song is trying to finish itself.

(Btw, the trick to getting the song out is to sing it all the way to the end. Give yourself that closure.)

So, why does this matter in business?

Bluma's experiment uncovers some fundamentals about how human brains work:

  • Our minds crave completion
  • We naturally obsess over unresolved stories
  • When something is unfinished, we pay closer attention

In writing, we usually refer to using the Zeigarnik Effect as creating an open loop or a curiosity gap.

It's why Netflix episodes end on a cliffhanger to drive binge-watching.

It's why email marketers write mysterious subject lines to boost open rates.

It's why, even though your audience wants answers, you shouldn't give them to them. At least, not right away.

Because if you have something valuable to share, if you want your stuff read and consumed, you've got to hold back too.

Or risk losing attention and getting skipped.

Cheers,

â

Rob Lennon

Founder, Lennon Labsâ

This email contains a critical lesson every content creator needs to know.

Now, I'm not explaining what that lesson is up front on purpose.

Science backs me up on this.

Quick storyâ¦

### The discovery goes back almost a hundred years, but it's more relevant today than it was back then.

Meet Bluma, a psychology student in Berlin.

Bluma becomes obsessed with how waiters and waitresses have exceptional memory for people's orders during service, but forget the orders just as quickly afterward.

That's odd, right?

You'd think that once you memorized someone's order that you'd memorized it?

Bluma has a theory why that's not true. This isn't just short-term memory. She recruits a bunch of volunteers to a test whose results will become her doctorate thesis.

### Here's how the experiment goes:

She gives each volunteer some simple puzzles and tasks. Half get to finish their tasks. Half are interrupted before they can finish their work.

Afterward, she asks each volunteer what tasks they remember most clearly.

Guess which tasks and puzzles they can't get out of their minds?

**It's the stuff they didn't finish.**

Makes sense right?

It's like incompleteness lingersâ¦ seeking closure.

Once we have closure, the mind stops working so hard on the idea, allowing it to slip from memory unless it's important for other reasons.

This lingering of unresolved thoughts becomes known as the Zeigarnik Effect after its discoverer, Bluma Zeigarnik.

This effect is the same reason a song gets stuck in your head. It's unresolved tension. The brain needs to complete it. Wants to resolve it. The song is trying to finish itself.

(Btw, the trick to getting the song out is to sing it all the way to the end. Give yourself that closure.)

### So, why does this matter in business?

Bluma's experiment uncovers some fundamentals about how human brains work:

*   Our minds crave completion
*   We naturally obsess over unresolved stories
*   When something is unfinished, we pay closer attention

In writing, we usually refer to using the Zeigarnik Effect as creating an open loop or a curiosity gap.

It's why Netflix episodes end on a cliffhanger to drive binge-watching.

It's why email marketers write mysterious subject lines to boost open rates.

It's why, even though your audience wants answers, you shouldn't give them to them. At least, not right away.

Because if you have something valuable to share, if you want your stuff read and consumed, you've got to hold back too.

Or risk losing attention and getting skipped.
